<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CRYPTO
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/06/el-salvadors-grand-bitcoin-experiment?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
El Salvador’s Grand Bitcoin Experiment
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/06/el-salvadors-grand-bitcoin-experiment?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="People are seen in a store where bitcoins are accepted in El Zonte, La L..." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MzAwL2VsX3NhbHZhZG9yLWVjb25vbXktY3J5cHQuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Marvin Recinos/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Welcome to El Salvador, where the pupusas are warm and the bitcoin is tender.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Today, the Central American nation will become the <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-09/el-salvador-s-bitcoin-bombshell-what-does-it-mean-quicktake?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">first sovereign state</a> to make bitcoin “legal tender,” meaning it’s now an official currency alongside the US dollar. In theory, El Salvadorans can now pay for anything—a haircut, house, or even taxes—using bitcoin. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The initiative is the <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/el-salvador-gets-ready-for-a-risky-bitcoin-experiment-11629966845?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">brainchild</a> of President Nayib Bukele, a 40-year-old populist whose approval rating of around 90% has emboldened him to reshape the country in his vision.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Why do this? </h2>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>One-quarter of El Salvador’s GDP comes from remittances—money sent back to the country from people working abroad. Bitcoin could reduce fees on those cross-border transactions.</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>It’s an attempt to bring more Salvarodans into the economic fold, the majority of whom don’t have a bank account.</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Bukele also thinks that, by being an early adopter, the country could become a destination for foreign investment in bitcoin mining. He wants to use geothermal energy from El Salvador’s volcanoes to power the energy-intensive mining process. </span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Like all experiments, this one could backfire</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Despite all the buzz around crypto, bitcoin hasn’t been used as an actual currency at scale before. As a business, it’s important to accept payment in currency that won’t plummet in value in the future. Bitcoin, however, has been known to be extremely volatile. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And because bitcoin by definition skirts traditional financial institutions that promote stability, the International Monetary Fund is concerned that El Salvador’s adoption of the crypto could create serious risks for the country’s economy. As a result, it downgraded El Salvador’s debt further into junk territory. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Other critics say the bitcoin move is a PR play to distract from Bukele’s <a href="https://www.latimes.com/world-nation/story/2021-09-06/as-el-salvador-adopts-bitcoin-its-young-president-is-dismantling-democracy?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">increasingly authoritarian tactics</a>. After his recent calls to “purge” the government’s judicial branch, his allies recently passed a law to remove one-third of the country’s judges and prosecutors. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>However this shakes out (and no one knows how it will), expect a lot of “I told you so”s from both sides of the debate. — <em>NF</em></p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENTERTAINMENT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/06/weibo-chinas-version-twitter-suspends-21-kpop-fan-accounts?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Weibo Tells K-Pop Fans: Kill This Club
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When Americans were all winding down from their second Saturday, Weibo—China’s version of Twitter—<a href="https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/06/tech/china-weibo-k-pop/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">suspended</a> at least 21 fan accounts for K-pop bands like BTS and Blackpink. In a statement that felt like the rules change ceremony in <em>Wife Swap,</em> the platform said it scrubbed the accounts to curb “irrational star-chasing behavior.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The purge began Sunday, when Weibo banned a BTS fan club with 1.1 million followers from posting for 60 days after it crowdsourced a birthday gift for Jimin (the cutest BTS member, keep up).</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>According to Weibo, collecting donations to customize </span><span><a href="https://twitter.com/JIMINBAR_CHINA/status/1432950201010982914?s=20" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">an airplane</a></span><span> for your fav vocalist contributes to the “chaos of fan clubs” that China wants to quell. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Later that day, Weibo said it would ban a number of other celebrity accounts in an effort to “purify” its platform. It cited a <a href="https://apnews.com/article/lifestyle-entertainment-business-religion-china-62dda0fc98601dd5afa3aa555a901b3f?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">government notice</a> from last Thursday about banning “vulgar internet celebrities” and feminine-looking men on TV. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> China’s entertainment industry has recently had to confront spikes in online censorship as the government cracks down on internet culture, which it considers unhealthy. Just last week, China <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/30/china-limits-online-video-games-three-hours-week-minors?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">limited</a> online video game playing to three hours a week for kids under 18. <em>– MM</em></p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
AVIATION
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/06/longer-waits-safer-planes-911-changed-air-travel?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Longer Waits, Safer Planes: How 9/11 Changed Air Travel
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/06/longer-waits-safer-planes-911-changed-air-travel?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="DENVER, COLORADO - JUNE 20, 2019: Airplane passengers line up for TSA se..." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83Mjk4L3RzYV9zZWN1cml0eV9saW5lc19hdF9kZW4uanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Robert Alexander/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>Leading up to the anniversary of the September 11 attacks this Saturday, we’ll feature stories that explore the economic impact of 9/11, 20 years later.</em></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Up today: air travel. After hijackers commandeered four planes the morning of September 11, 2001, the US <a href="https://apnews.com/article/how-sept-11-changed-flying-1ce4dc4282fb47a34c0b61ae09a024f4?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">revamped</a> its process for airport security screening to prevent similar attacks. Here are some important things to know. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The TSA is born: </strong>Pre-9/11, the US relied on private companies to screen passengers before flights. Only in November 2001 did the government create the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to handle security at airports. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">New security measures: </strong>Over the years, TSA responded to new threats by adding new restrictions. In 2006, it limited the amounts of liquids, gels, and aerosols you could bring on a plane, boosting the mini toothpaste tube industry. In 2010, TSA began installing full body scanners after the “underwear bomber” tried to detonate a device hidden under his clothing.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Airlines took a hit: </strong>Airline revenue for domestic US flights <a href="https://www.cnn.com/travel/article/air-travel-after-9-11/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">fell by $10 billion/year</a> from 2001–2006. But that’s nothing compared to the financial hurt from the Covid-19 pandemic, when global airlines lost $126.4 billion in 2020.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Beefed-up airport screening has created more hassle for passengers, but has also largely rooted out potential attacks. Now, a privacy debate is unfolding over how “trusted traveler” programs like PreCheck collect and protect the sensitive personal info of Americans. — <em>NF</em></p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In addition to offering life insurance solutions, Prudential can be a source for financial planning and investing so you can weather tricky times and reach your goals. </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
JOBS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/09/06/study-shows-automated-rsum-scanner-mistakenly-rejects-millions-viable-job-candidates?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Robo Recruiters Have a Patchy Track Record
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Job illustration" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zNjQ1L2pvYl9pbGx1c3RyYXRpb24uanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Waiting to hear back for a job interview? Your résumé might never have gotten into human hands. Popular software used by companies to screen job applicants has filtered out more than 10 million potential employees, new <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/companies-need-more-workers-why-do-they-reject-millions-of-resumes-11630728008?mod=djemalertNEWS" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Harvard Business School research</a> shows.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How does the tech work?</strong> An automatic screener largely relies on “negative” logic to reduce the size of the applicant pool. Résumés—even those of well-qualified candidates—can get lost in a black hole because of things like a gap in the applicant’s employment history, a lack of certain credentials, or keywords that don’t match up with the job description.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Some of those keywords might not seem obvious. Hospitals set “computer programming” as a keyword when they look for registered nurses who can enter patient data into a computer, Joseph Fuller, Harvard’s lead researcher for the study, explained to the WSJ.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why it matters</strong>: 99% of Fortune 500 companies and 75% of the US employers Harvard surveyed use an automated scanner to initially filter applicants. While there are <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/07/there-are-about-1-million-more-job-openings-than-people-looking-for-work.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">10 million job openings</a> in the US that employers desperately want to fill, automated hiring systems are excluding viable candidates. <em>– SQ</em></p>

collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWelcome to El Salvador, where the pupusas are warm and the bitcoin is tender.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eToday, the Central American nation will become the \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-09/el-salvador-s-bitcoin-bombshell-what-does-it-mean-quicktake?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efirst sovereign state\u003c/a\u003e to make bitcoin “legal tender,” meaning it’s now an official currency alongside the US dollar. In theory, El Salvadorans can now pay for anything—a haircut, house, or even taxes—using bitcoin. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe initiative is the \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/el-salvador-gets-ready-for-a-risky-bitcoin-experiment-11629966845?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebrainchild\u003c/a\u003e of President Nayib Bukele, a 40-year-old populist whose approval rating of around 90% has emboldened him to reshape the country in his vision.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhy do this? \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOne-quarter of El Salvador’s GDP comes from remittances—money sent back to the country from people working abroad. Bitcoin could reduce fees on those cross-border transactions.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIt’s an attempt to bring more Salvarodans into the economic fold, the majority of whom don’t have a bank account.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBukele also thinks that, by being an early adopter, the country could become a destination for foreign investment in bitcoin mining. He wants to use geothermal energy from El Salvador’s volcanoes to power the energy-intensive mining process. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eLike all experiments, this one could backfire\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eDespite all the buzz around crypto, bitcoin hasn’t been used as an actual currency at scale before. As a business, it’s important to accept payment in currency that won’t plummet in value in the future. Bitcoin, however, has been known to be extremely volatile. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd because bitcoin by definition skirts traditional financial institutions that promote stability, the International Monetary Fund is concerned that El Salvador’s adoption of the crypto could create serious risks for the country’s economy. As a result, it downgraded El Salvador’s debt further into junk territory. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOther critics say the bitcoin move is a PR play to distract from Bukele’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.latimes.com/world-nation/story/2021-09-06/as-el-salvador-adopts-bitcoin-its-young-president-is-dismantling-democracy?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eincreasingly authoritarian tactics\u003c/a\u003e. After his recent calls to “purge” the government’s judicial branch, his allies recently passed a law to remove one-third of the country’s judges and prosecutors. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eHowever this shakes out (and no one knows how it will), expect a lot of “I told you so”s from both sides of the debate. — \u003cem\u003eNF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" Club\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhen Americans were all winding down from their second Saturday, Weibo—China’s version of Twitter—\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/06/tech/china-weibo-k-pop/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esuspended\u003c/a\u003e at least 21 fan accounts for K-pop bands like BTS and Blackpink. In a statement that felt like the rules change ceremony in \u003cem\u003eWife Swap,\u003c/em\u003e the platform said it scrubbed the accounts to curb “irrational star-chasing behavior.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe purge began Sunday, when Weibo banned a BTS fan club with 1.1 million followers from posting for 60 days after it crowdsourced a birthday gift for Jimin (the cutest BTS member, keep up).\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAccording to Weibo, collecting donations to customize \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/JIMINBAR_CHINA/status/1432950201010982914?s=20\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ean airplane\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e for your fav vocalist contributes to the “chaos of fan clubs” that China wants to quell. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLater that day, Weibo said it would ban a number of other celebrity accounts in an effort to “purify” its platform. It cited a \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/lifestyle-entertainment-business-religion-china-62dda0fc98601dd5afa3aa555a901b3f?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003egovernment notice\u003c/a\u003e from last Thursday about banning “vulgar internet celebrities” and feminine-looking men on TV. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture:\u003c/strong\u003e China’s entertainment industry has recently had to confront spikes in online censorship as the government cracks down on internet culture, which it considers unhealthy. Just last week, China \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/30/china-limits-online-video-games-three-hours-week-minors?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elimited\u003c/a\u003e online video game playing to three hours a week for kids under 18. collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eLeading up to the anniversary of the September 11 attacks this Saturday, we’ll feature stories that explore the economic impact of 9/11, 20 years later.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eUp today: air travel. After hijackers commandeered four planes the morning of September 11, 2001, the US \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/how-sept-11-changed-flying-1ce4dc4282fb47a34c0b61ae09a024f4?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erevamped\u003c/a\u003e its process for airport security screening to prevent similar attacks. Here are some important things to know. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe TSA is born: \u003c/strong\u003ePre-9/11, the US relied on private companies to screen passengers before flights. Only in November 2001 did the government create the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to handle security at airports. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eNew security measures: \u003c/strong\u003eOver the years, TSA responded to new threats by adding new restrictions. In 2006, it limited the amounts of liquids, gels, and aerosols you could bring on a plane, boosting the mini toothpaste tube industry. In 2010, TSA began installing full body scanners after the “underwear bomber” tried to detonate a device hidden under his clothing.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eAirlines took a hit: \u003c/strong\u003eAirline revenue for domestic US flights \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/travel/article/air-travel-after-9-11/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efell by $10 billion/year\u003c/a\u003e from 2001–2006. But that’s nothing compared to the financial hurt from the Covid-19 pandemic, when global airlines lost $126.4 billion in 2020.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eBeefed-up airport screening has created more hassle for passengers, but has also largely rooted out potential attacks. Now, a privacy debate is unfolding over how “trusted traveler” programs like PreCheck collect and protect the sensitive personal info of Americans. style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWaiting to hear back for a job interview? Your résumé might never have gotten into human hands. Popular software used by companies to screen job applicants has filtered out more than 10 million potential employees, new \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/companies-need-more-workers-why-do-they-reject-millions-of-resumes-11630728008?mod=djemalertNEWS\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eHarvard Business School research\u003c/a\u003e shows.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow does the tech work?\u003c/strong\u003e An automatic screener largely relies on “negative” logic to reduce the size of the applicant pool. Résumés—even those of well-qualified candidates—can get lost in a black hole because of things like a gap in the applicant’s employment history, a lack of certain credentials, or keywords that don’t match up with the job description.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSome of those keywords might not seem obvious. Hospitals set “computer programming” as a keyword when they look for registered nurses who can enter patient data into a computer, Joseph Fuller, Harvard’s lead researcher for the study, explained to the WSJ.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy it matters\u003c/strong\u003e: 99% of Fortune 500 companies and 75% of the US employers Harvard surveyed use an automated scanner to initially filter applicants. While there are \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/07/there-are-about-1-million-more-job-openings-than-people-looking-for-work.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e10 million job openings\u003c/a\u003e in the US that employers desperately want to fill, automated
